thread.title: Treasurer Joe Hockey wins $200k in defamation case against Fairfax Media
thread.title_full: Treasurer Joe Hockey wins $200k in defamation case against Fairfax Media

author: CAMERON ENGLAND
title: Treasurer Joe Hockey wins $200k in defamation case against Fairfax Media
text:
TREASURER Joe Hockey has won $200,000 in a defamation case against Fairfax Media.
The Federal Court today decided Fairfax had defamed Mr Hockey with a newsstand poster and two tweets relating to a story it published on May 5, 2014, with the headline ‘Treasurer for Sale’.
They will need to pay Mr Hockey $120,000 in damages for the poster and $80,000 for the tweets.
Mr Hockey was not awarded any damages for the article itself.
The article extensively probed Mr Hockey’s links to an organisation called the North Sydney Forum, with the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age suggesting high-powered business and industry leaders were paying excessive memberships to meet and hold policy dialogue with the Treasurer.
The court previously heard the article was potentially payback, with the editor of the Sydney Morning Herald , Darren Goodsir, ordering a dirt file be “nailed to the cross” against Mr Hockey because he was angry about being forced to apologise for an incorrect story.
The Federal Court in December last year heard Goodsir wrote in a text he felt “pissed off” Mr Hockey’s press secretary rang him at 2.15am to complain about a story on March 21. Mr Hockey also rang Goodsir’s boss, Fairfax chief executive Greg Hywood.
The Herald was forced to apologise for a mistake in the story about the Treasurer and the campaign fundraising body North Sydney Forum.
“They have a f ... ing hide,’’ Goodsir texted his Fairfax colleague, The Age editor-in-chief Andrew Holden.
Holden advised Goodsir to “dig” into the fundraising body (NSF) and “in that story you can run Hockey’s claim he knew nothing ... beyond that, f. him”.
That day, Goodsir instructed Herald state political editor Sean Nicholls to “drop all other work and be full time digging into NSF”.
After receiving an update on Mr Nicholls’ work on March 27, Quote: : ‘F ... ing brilliant! ... Given what Andrew and I endured last week with Hockey, I want to have this nailed to the cross in more ways that one.’’
The article, published May 5 on the front page of the Herald and The Age , said that in return for annual fees of up to $22,000, NSF members were rewarded with “VIP” meetings with Mr Hockey.
Fairfax has argued the article contained correct factual material and the company did not intend to infer Mr Hockey was corrupt.
Mr Hockey has claimed he was devastated by the suggestion he was corrupt. He was seeking a damages payout of potentially more than $1 million.
Defamation payouts are capped at $366,000 per matter, but aggravated damages can go higher.
Under cross-examination, Mr Goodsir said he formulated the ‘Treasurer for Sale’ headline the day before the story was printed, before the Treasurer had a chance to respond to or refute 13 implicit questions sent to his office about allegations he was offering privileged access to business leaders at a substantial cost.
But he denied the headline implied Mr Hockey was corrupt.
“So you chose to write the words -Treasurer for sale’’ without knowing how my client would respond to those questions?’’ Mr Hockey’s counsel Bruce McClintock asked.
Mr Goodsir: “That’s fair.’’ Mr McClintock: “Did it occur to you that you should raise such serious allegations with my client?’’
Mr Goodsir: “No, it did not.” He later acknowledged that he thought the headline was “fair” and “truthful”, although admitted the words could be taken as claiming the Treasurer could be bought.
Mr McClintock: “Treasurer for sale equates to treasurer can be bought. And Treasurer can be bought equates to Treasure is corrupt, doesn’t it?’’
Mr Goodsir: “I do not agree with that.”
Mr Goodsir conceded he was “mildly irritated” at Mr Hockey for complaining directly to Fairfax Media’s CEO and seeking an apology before coming to him first, but said he was not motivated by revenge.
Originally published as Hockey’s $200,000 payday from Fairfax
